title: Prove to me with video evidence how ADC can 1v3 and win their lane
body:
"No amount of experimentation can ever prove me right; a single experiment can prove me wrong." - Albert Einstein

if 50% win rate is what one will achieve being average relative to the performance of every other player in the game. For one to achieve a desired win rate, they will need to be 5 times the win rate in effectiveness relative to the average of every player in their game.

For example, to achieve an 80% win rate, they will need to be 30% over the average which is 50%. So 30% multiplied by 5 is 150%.

being 150% more effective than the average of the players on your team means you will have to be a total of 250% effective to the average of your teammates.

I believe ridiculously strongly that luck plays the initial part of winning the game, if the luck is too far out of your favour, then your actions do not become relevant to the relevant outcome of a game. (win or loss)

Over 3 years it has not been proven to me exactly how and why everyone claims that luck is mostly about skill and has very little to do with luck.

So I would like video evidence of how an ADC can play out and STOMP a standard bot lane while their support is severely handicapped, in essence, a 1v3.

I have been told it is easy for them to do, but I have looked up and could not find any video evidence of this event occuring.

I have been told they consistently can achieve an 80% win rate and this is basically the requirement to achieve it.

Would someone kindly take the time to prove me wrong with video evidence?

You have valid points my friend. No one can 1v3 as adc and win. All it takes is 3 noobs to use 3 ultimates on you and you've lost. There have been times i have pwned 2-3 players as an adc. But 100% that was always with an advantage, like they were low health or my turret was killing them. It's not a sustainable lane state.

Matchmaking is accurate but it doesn't use LP or rank, it uses the mmr algorithm based on the elo system and bets for you or against you. You'll likely never have a 50/50 chance game to gain 20lp or lose 20lp. It's probably more like '40% chance of winning against this stronger opponent, for 50 points of their elo (+50 you, -50 them), and 60% chance of losing, giving them 25 points of your elo (-25 you, +25 them)'. If you win, you get the higher share cos odds were against you, but if you lose, you only lose a little. Then Riot tries to make it less confusing by slotting you into divisions with an Lp rating.

It could just be at the moment matchmaker is betting against you because it thinks you should be a lower elo.

Players who start losing games find they just cant seem to get a good matchup over a whole series - from 10 to 20 games even - they start blaming themselves and their teams - but really its because matchmaker keeps slotting them into 40/60 games and betting against them. Eventually you'll start playing games that you just can't lose cos your opponents are so bad, and matchmaker will start a reversal of 60/40 games.

If you get into a 40/60 game you need to be calm and focused - the upset win could be yours! Then you'll show matchmaker who's boss!

That is not how mmr works, that is how LP gain and loss works.

mmr will only give you less per loss and more per win if the enemy team average mmr relative to your teams is higher.

Your LP gain and loss is then exclusively attributed to your current rank and mmr relative to each other.

I wrote a wall of text explaining why you have valid points.

What I was saying was you can't get an accurate 50/50 chance game. You'll get the odds stacked against you or for you in regards to mmr right from the moment you click 'accept'. It has a massive impact on your win chance.

Then there are more odds - how tired/tilted are you teammates, are they looking to win or try a champ? is this a good comp? will they play aggressive or defensive? Will they hit their combos?

The 'luck' is really just a compounding effect of different odds.

Sometimes the game is just handed to you, regardless of your individual effort. All the odds are in your favor. But to win a game when the odd's aren't in your favor... through exceeding all expectations of you... through transcending your rank and being more then a calculated number... to win when everything is unlucky, by being the one thing that is lucky... that's the skill component.

So yes, luck plays a massive part in winning.

But you can fight luck with skill.

But sometimes you can beat fate, maybe 1/20 games you do something extraordinary and go supersaiyan. You win 5 more then you lose in 100 games. That's 50 out of 1000 games. After 1000 games, 50 games is the difference between being silver at the start of the season and gold by the end.

Hopefully you can get a better ratio then 1/20.

I strive for 1/5. Win three, lose two, win three, lose two, sometimes win four, sometimes lose three...

Thus, thinking more about it, your winrate is really about how many games you beat the odds compared to how many games you don't. If you're on 80%, you played ten games, and you won five as you were supposed to, and lost 2 as you were supposed to, but in three of them you were meant to lose but you came out strong. Maybe you did one thing that changed everything in those games, like you roamed mid once and snowballed. 

Instead of thinking you have to be 150% better for that 80%, like everyone else says is possible, think, i just need 3 moments of greatness in ten games. 

Undoubtedly, those 3 moments will come out of practice. You also need to not fail in the games you're meant to win - consistency that comes from practice.

...what?

Winrate does not = skill. Winrate = skill relative to your rank. i.e If you are in Silver 2 with a winrate of 70% you probably belong in gold somewhere, or if you are S2 with a winrate of 30% you probably belong in Bronze somewhere.

What is all this about you have to be better than your teammates? That doesn't make any sense at all. The idea is to be better than the enemy, as a team. You are being matched with them (and against them) because your skill (i.e your mmr) is approximately equal to theirs. There are a lot of other factors in play of course, but that is what it comes down to.

As for luck, If anything, luck only comes into play later in the game, when one wrong move or teamfight can cost you the game, but even so can you really call that luck if it is a conscious decision? Sure you may have been wrong or misjudged the situation, but that doesn't mean you were unlucky, it means you made a mistake.

In the early game it's all about your game knowledge and mechanics, early game is pretty much the purest test of skill there is, because you don't have items, there is no fed enemies or feeding allies, it comes down to raw skill and strategy. 

How have you set up your runes/masteries to counter your lane opponent? Have you picked a champion that counters them or is a skill matchup? Is their positioning better than yours? How good are they at cs-ing? And so on and so forth.

That aside, where does this assumption come from that your support is going to be sub-par compared to the enemy? Or that ADCs have to be able to 1v3 to be able to win games? Or that "it is easy for them to do"?

Has it ever occurred to you that maybe you simply aren't playing to your potential? That you aren't making a conscious effort to learn and that maybe that is why you aren't climbing?

Your builds, your runes and masteries, heck even your summoners prove you think you know better, but if something isn't working for you, and if multiple people you consider to be good at the game (i.e Diamond+) have told you what you could be doing instead that will probably work better and you aren't changing anything, then why would you expect to be climbing? 

That's like trying to put a square peg in a round hole, having someone suggest you use the round peg, or at least a rounder peg, you insisting that the square peg is better and it has to be perfectly square and it should go in but the hole is against you and proceeding to try cramming that square peg in that round hole for years over thousands of games. 

It just doesn't make any sense.
